discussion.content:
True 
import math
print(dir(math))
print(type(dir(math))) # <class 'list'>
print(type(dir(math)) is list) # True
print(type(dir(math)[0])) # <class 'str'>
print(type(dir(math)[0]) is str) # True

import sys
print(type(dir(sys.path))) # <class 'list'>
print(type(dir(sys.path)) is list) # True
print(type(dir(sys.path)[-1])) # <class 'str'>
print(type(dir(sys.path)[-1]) is str) # True

//IMG//

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AB
A. import pymod 
pymod.pyfun()

B. from pymod import pyfun 
pyfun()
There is no any correct answer if each statement write in a single line.

discussion.content:
pymod.py file contains =>

pyvar = 1
def pyfun():
 print(pyvar)


python3 =>

>>> import pymod
>>> pymod.pyfun()
1
>>> from pymod import pyfun
>>> pyfun()
1
>>> from pymod import *
>>> pymod.pyfun()
1
>>> import pyfun from pymod
 File "<stdin>", line 1
 import pyfun from pymod
 ^
SyntaxError: invalid syntax

A,B, C are all correct. But B is better than C.

Best answer : A & B
Yes, it's AB

questions.question_text:
A Python module named pymod.py contains a function named pyfun().
Which of the following snippets will let you invoke the function? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
BD are correct.
__name__ variable contains the name of a module, not of a package

Selected Answer: BD
The B is correct because a Package is s a group of related modules, and D it's a semi-compiled python packages.

Selected Answer: BD
BD are correct

Selected Answer: BD
B. a package is a group of related modules
D. the pyc extension is used to mark semi-compiled Python packages

Selected Answer: BC
BC is the correct answer

The rest is wrong because:
A: Packages doesn't need to end with a *.pa suffix
D: *.pyc are compiled already, not pre-compiled

questions.question_text: What is true about Python packages? (Choose two.)

choices.B: a package is a group of related modules
choices.C: the __name__ variable always contains the name of a package
choices.D: the pyc extension is used to mark semi-compiled Python packages
choices.A: a package is a single file whose name ends with the pa extension

This is an interesting debate, but it's easy to test.
Running the snippet in Visual Studio Code outputs a single line. It KINDA looks like two lines, but only because we're using an *. Change the * to a X and it becomes clear to see the output is only a single line.
You can also, as way of a second test, replace the * in the else block with *\n. Doing so clearly prints 2 lines.
If YOU are seeing something different then it seems likely to be a fluke of the interpreter, and not the code.
pcap-31-03 or pcap-31-02

Correct answer is three (A)
For python 3.7.9
https://ibb.co/WPkTL2q

comments.content:
You're image suggests the output "***".
However, if you look at the question, it asks for the line count; of which, is B: one line.

If the question was how many "*" or how many times the script would loop, you would then be correct.

discussion.content:

The answer is B, there is not "\n" so all is printed in the same line.

The end="" affects everything inside the loop, including the else block. I had to check within the Python interpretor, but the end="" does indeed affect everything. As such, after ** the else block adds * to the same line which results in the final output being *** on one line.
The correct answer is B.
There is a debate here but to me, it is obvious that just one line is printed and arguments about that two lines are printed are not making me change my mind... This is just a stupid question

This only prints one line. This is because the end="" means that there is not a space after its done printing. Normally a new print line (from the else block) would make a new line but doesn't because of the end keyword used in the preceeding for block.
Its two lines. Because when the else blocks runs it adds a new line. By default print() method sets the value of sep variable to "\n". Thats why we see the second line empty.
